datafield.subfield: Static Einstein-Maxwell black holes with no spatial isometries in AdS space
Static black holes with no spatial isometries in AdS-electrovacuum
Static Einstein-Maxwell black holes with no spatial isometries in AdS space
5 pages, 4 figures; v2. change in title to comply with PRL requirements. Version published in Physical Review Letters

We explicitly construct static black hole solutions to the fully non-linear, D=4, Einstein-Maxwell-AdS equations that have no continuous spatial symmetries. These black holes have a smooth, topologically spherical horizon (section), but without isometries, and approach, asymptotically, global AdS spacetime. They are interpreted as bound states of a horizon with the Einstein-Maxwell-AdS solitons recently discovered, for appropriate boundary data. In sharp contrast with the uniqueness results for Minkowski electrovacuum, the existence of these black holes shows that single, equilibrium, BH solutions in AdS-electrovacuum admit an arbitrary multipole structure.

00017 Examples of isometric embeddings for the horizon of $AdS$-electrovacuum BHs (top), together with their horizon Ricci scalar (bottom). The boundary data is given by the harmonics with $(\ell,m)$ equal to $(2,2)$ (left), $(3,2)$ (middle) and $(3,3)$ (right).

00020 Equatorial slices for isometric embeddings of the horizons of $AdS$-electrovacuum BHs with different boundary data. The BHs have the same temperature and increasing values of the parameter $c_e$, starting with $c_e=0$ (center).

00021 Equatorial slices for isometric embeddings of the horizons of $AdS$-electrovacuum BHs with different boundary data. The BHs have the same temperature and increasing values of the parameter $c_e$, starting with $c_e=0$ (center).

00019 Examples of isometric embeddings for the horizon of $AdS$-electrovacuum BHs (top), together with their horizon Ricci scalar (bottom). The boundary data is given by the harmonics with $(\ell,m)$ equal to $(2,2)$ (left), $(3,2)$ (middle) and $(3,3)$ (right).

00011 Examples of surfaces of constant energy density for the Maxwell-$AdS$ regular electric multipoles with (from left to right): $(\ell,m)=\left\{(1,0), (1,1)\right\}$ (top row); $(\ell,m)=\left\{(2,0), (2,1), (2,2)\right\}$ (second row); $(\ell,m)=\left\{(3,0), (3,1), (3,2), (3,3)\right\}$ (third row); $(\ell,m)=\left\{(4,0), (4,1), (4,2), (4,3), (4,4)\right\}$ (fourth row). Here, we are defining standard Cartesian coordinates from the global $AdS$ coordinates, using the standard formulas. All plots in this work use units with $L=G=1$.

D. Kastor and J. H. Traschen

This is, however, no golden rule. A famous example are spherically symmetric boson stars, which admit no black hole generalization [46]. This example emphasizes that symmetry compatibility between the soliton and horizon is a non-trivial necessary condition to place the latter inside the former
C. A. R. Herdeiro and E. Radu
M. S. Volkov and D. V. Galtsov
M. S. Volkov and D. V. Galtsov

A Course of Modern Analysis, Cambridge Mathematical Library (Cambridge University Press,)
This value differs from the one in [30] due to a different normalization of the spherical harmonics
O. J. C. Dias et al.
As a further test of our solutions, we have verified the Gauss-Bonnet theorem holds at the level of the numerical accuracy, by integrating the horizon Ricci scalar over the horizon
